Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: One aircraft is about to cross into the neighboring sector on a normal route.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a message from Alex: “Which night should we do our date? I’m free all week, just want to see you.” My heart warms—he’s been looking forward to this, and so have I. We promised to make more time for each other, to not let work always come first. But as I start to type a reply, my headset crackles. “Sector boundary handoff in two minutes,” my colleague reminds me. I check the radar: Flight 482 is approaching the edge of my airspace, and I need to coordinate with the next controller to ensure a seamless handoff. It’s routine, but timing is everything. I can’t afford distraction, not even for a second. My phone buzzes again—Alex, waiting for an answer. I feel the tug between wanting to be present for him and knowing that, right now, hundreds of lives depend on my focus. My fingers hover over the keyboard, my mind split, the weight of both roles pressing in as I try to decide which expectation to meet first.
